of the population and are spread throughout
the territory in hundreds of towns
and villages. They are called Palestinians in memory of the Philistine people in antiquity. Before the arrival of the British, they lived under
the empire of the Turks for four centuries. Watch these color images shot
at the beginning of the 20th century. Their oriental culture
has always fascinated visitors. Some of them are Bedouins. They live in the desert
with their herds, but most of them are peasants. They work for great
Arab landowners, like here, on the coastal plain, where the famous Jaffa oranges
are produced. They are exported
 all over the world. For several years now, some Arab owners have agree
to sell their land to the Zionists. And little by little, the face of Palestine is changing. In 1935, Jews already represented
30% of the population, they created dozens of villages
along the coast and in the north. This does not prevent
most Arab families from living the pre-war years
without mistrust and in a certain welfare. This is the case, in Jerusalem,
for the Saïd family. Christian Arabs who own
a publishing house. Filmed by his father
during summer vacation, this boy is called Edward. He is the future Palestinian writer
 Edward Saïd. Our family home was in Talbiya, a neighborhood of
Palestinian Christians like us. The imposing two-storey villa
had many bedrooms and a lovely garden in which
my two younger cousins, my sisters and I could play. It was an idyllic time. On their family movie, nothing yet suggests
that this idyllic period is about to end. At the same time, in Germany. The situation becomes
dramatic for the Jews. The Nazis who seek to create
an ethnically pure country, multiplied provocations and anti-Semitic inscriptions
are spread throughout the country. On the trams and even on public benches. on public benches. At the Nuremberg Congress in 1935, the Nazis officially exclude Jews
from the national community. Among German Jews,
panic begins to set in and more and more people
are seeking to flee abroad, to France, Great Britain, or the United States. This is where a Jewish community
of 4 million people already lives. But visas for Western countries
are granted in dribs and drabs. Thus, more than 100,000 German Jews
 choose Palestine where the doors of immigration
are still open to them. A hundred Jewish families
arrive in Palestine aboard the Mariette Pacha, of the
 Compagnie des Messageries Maritimes. Most of them are
in absolute poverty, the laws of the Reich prohibiting Jews
 from transferring their property. The Zionist associations welcome
these unfortunate people and give them the means
to rebuild their lives. Among the passengers on the
Mariette Pacha are the Weilers, our Jewish family from Berlin. Unlike the other passengers, the Weilers come
as simple visitors. Without knowing yet whether
they will settle in Palestine with their two little girls and leave Germany definitively. They continue to film
with their personal cameras. To convince his wife, Friedrich Weiler
 shows her around the country. He takes her to the shores
of the Dead Sea. They visit Tel Aviv, the Jewish metropolis
of 130,000 inhabitants, emerged from the ground
in less than 20 years. They visit German friends
who are already settled there. However, after a week of travel, they are still hesitant
to take the plunge. In Jerusalem, they found a city in turmoil, close to revolt. At the call of the grand mufti, Palestinian Arabs demonstrate
against British occupier and its policy favorable
to the mass arrival of Jews. One of their spokespeople explains. Since the beginning
of the 1930s, demonstrations follow
one another in Palestine. Getting more and more violent. Attacks on kibbutz, attacks in the middle of the street. In 1936, what is called the Great
Arab Revolt finally broke out. One of its leaders is called
Fawzi al-Qawuqji. He launched the guerrilla war
against the British army. We rebel against injustice, against Zionism, to defend our Holy Land. The English abused Arab blood. Today, we are ready
to face them. In a few months, the revolt
spreads all over Palestine and forces the British
to send reinforcements. The repression is relentless. Like here, in Jaffa where a neighborhood
is emptied of its inhabitants and razed. It takes the British army two years
to put down the revolt, but it's only temporary. In 1938, on one of the Arab peasants
taken prisoner, we find a leaflet which sounds like a warning. Today, you are cruelly trying to
strip us of our rights, of our houses, of our honor. Know that never, not before having
conquered our freedom, will we lay down our arms. The same year, in Germany. The date is November 9, 1938. In front of the population which
observes and sometimes approves, the Nazis set fire to the places
of worship of the Jews. It's Kristallnacht. A gigantic pogrom during which
8,000 shops are ransacked and a hundred Jews are murdered. A few months ago, Germany took control of Austria where 200,000 Jews live. In a new outburst of anti-Semitism, tension rises sharply in Europe and the risk of a new world war
draws near. Some Jews in Europe realize that
for them, the countdown has begun. Shortly before Kristallnacht, The Weilers made the decision
to leave Berlin for good and to emigrate to Palestine. On the photos taken before departure,
the parents try to put on a good face, but Friedrich notes
in his journal: “We are spending the last
few days in fear.” "Until the end I feared
that the Gestapo" "would ask us for
an additional formality." “Last night, my mother thought she was
suffocating at the thought of us leaving.” Friedrich's mother, Ida, decided to stay in Germany. She tries to reassure
her granddaughters. Nazis. It's nothing to worry about. We have them
only for a while. All that, you'll see, will pass. Berlin. the day of departure. The parents take final photos
on the dock. The grandmother, Ida, came to say
 goodbye to the whole family. Ella, her granddaughter,
here on the right, is excited. is excited. She doesn't realize it's the last time
 she's seeing her grandmother. I am excited about this trip. A new life is beginning. We're crossing Austria where Hitler has just
taken power. We're crossing the Alps. It's the first time I've seen
such big mountains. And then that's it,
we find ourselves in Italy. The Nazis, with their viciousness,
are behind us. The family embarked for Palestine. Our boat is called the Jerusalem. To pass the time, my mom knits, and I read books all day long. After five days at sea,
the Weilers land in Palestine. The parents have chosen to settle
in a small house north of Tel Aviv where they think their two daughters
will be able to grow up safely. They will soon learn that
they are among the last to have been able to
reach Palestine. Because in the spring of 1939, the situation changed abruptly. Great Britain, which is still
occupying Palestine, makes a decision that calls
everything into question. To secure the support of the Arabs
in the next war against Hitler, the British decide to stop
supporting Zionism. To limit the number of entry visas
for Jews as well as purchases of land. A catastrophic decision for the Zionists who intended to make millions
of Jews to emigrate from Europe before the outbreak of war. Their leader in Palestine, David Ben Gurion, in turn,
chose force through. He decides to accelerate the
operations towers and palisades, these creations of colonies which multiplied in previous years and which rely on
the effect of surprise. It is July 12, 1939, 
n Negba, near the Negev Desert. The Zionist militants have
been loaded a convoy of prefabricated houses
which they will install here. On those lands they previously
bought from the Arabs. Among them is Joël Iglinskiy. “You have to go fast.” “Everyone knows what to do.” “You build palisades by putting
gravel inside the planks” “to stop the bullets.” “We're going up the watchtower.” “We forget the fatigue” “because we are the soldiers
of the Zionist revolution” “and we know that we're doing
something bigger than ourselves.” In the summer of 1939, as the
cataclysm that was about to come, Jews held their breath. Some, as we have shown, sought refuge by emigrating
to Palestine. Others still hope to continue
living in Europe espite the danger. It will only take a few months for them
 to achieve the unimaginable. The project of the destruction of
an entire population by the Nazis. It is this new chapter that we are
now going to tell you about. September 1, 1939, Germany invades Poland. It is the beginning of
the Second World War. From the first weeks, the Nazis,
who crushed the Polish army, increased the exactions. Forced labor, beaatings, humiliations, as shown by dozens of photos
taken all over the country, of German soldiers
unleashing on Jews. Hitler ordered the Polish Jews
to be grouped together, men, women and children, in quarters reserved for them, the ghettos. The Nazis chose to isolate their
future victims from the rest of the world, to starve them little by little, before, soon, deciding to
murder them en masse, here. The massacre began
a year and a half later, on 22 June 1941, when the German army
attacks the USSR. A lightning offensive which,
in a few days, pushes the Soviets back
hundreds of kilometers. In the conquered cities, the Nazis immediately launched
the persecutions against the Jews with the help of the population. Everywhere, like here in Zloczow, pro-German nationalists, far right activists and defendants launch pogroms under the encouragement
of the Germans. They accuse Jews of being
responsible for massacres which were committed by
the Soviets a few days earlier. In Lvov, Ukraine, a German soldier films the crowd
and the Ukrainian militiamen. Dozens of Jewish women, after being raped, will be murdered
along with their families. An SS sergeant, Félix Landau,
despite being ferociously antisemitic, is surprised by
this outburst of violence. “We're seeing things that are
almost impossible to describe.” “Hundreds of Jews
covered in blood,” “holes in their heads,” “broken hands” “and eyes hanging out
of their sockets” “because of the hits” “full of hate” “and anger.” In a few hours, the massacre
spread to dozens of cities. Again on the 4th of July, Germans approach
Kaunas in Lithuania. This is where Dita Katz
and her whole family live. Do you remember that film
shot twelve years earlier, in 1929? When the Germans arrive, the
grandfather tries to reassure his family. “Don't be afraid of the Germans.” “I knew them during
the First World War.” “They are civilized people.” However, from the very first hours, his own son Itzhak disappears
at the corner of a street. The rest is told by
a German corporal. “Lithuanians with sticks and crowbars,” “hit the Jews to the ground,” “on the skull or on the face.” "Without distinction," "they are beaten" “until they no longer show
any signs of life.” “In three quarters of an hour,” “the one who is presented
as the executioner of the city” killed fifty people." “All around, the Germans
are watching the show.” In Bavaria, from his mountain chalet, Hitler approves pogroms. But he wants to frame and rationalize them. He instructed Heinrich Himmler,
the head of the SS, here on the left, to set up special units:
the Einsatzgruppen. Their mission is to remove
within a few months any trace of the Jewish people
on the conquered territories. The Einsatzgruppen will shoot
Jews directly into mass graves. In Libau, not far from Kaunas, the soldier of the German navy, Reinhardt Wiener, films one of these massacres
with his personal camera. A truck is coming. Guards force Jews
to jump off. There are weak and sick people
among them, they help each other out. They are pushed towards
the trench by an SS. When they get to the trench, they have to walk over bodies
covered in sand, the firing squad
stands in front of them, they are told to turn around waiting for the next group to arrive. The scale of the massacre
is unparalleled in history. In six months, the Einsatzgruppen murdered
half a million Jews. In front of his troops, Himmler gave the order. “What to do with women
and children?” “I don't think we can exterminate men” “and at the same time let
their children become adults” “so that they can take revenge on
our children and grandchildren later.” At the end of 1941, information about the genocide
begins to filter in. In Palestine, the Arab population remains
aloof from the conflict. Even though its spiritual leader,
the Grand Mufti of Jerusalem, exiled by the British,
chose to collaborate with Hitler. He raised a regiment of
pro-Nazi Bosnian Muslims. The Jews, on the other hand,
are alarmed to stop receiving news
from their loved ones. This is the case for Mickaël Arens, the young Zionist from Riga,
who arrived in Palestine in 1938 and who joined the police force. He is unaware that his mother, who remained in Latvia, was killed in the first days
of the German offensive. Friedrich Weiler, too, can no longer
communicate with his mother, Ida stayed in Berlin. On November 2, 1941,
he wrote in his journal. “Horrible news from Germany.” “The Jews here are being
deported from their homes” “and sent like cattle to Poland.” “This news is so inhuman" "that it's hard to believe it.” “They are asked to dig" "and they are slaughtered
in these graves.” In November 1941, Ida Weiler, the grandmother, has
already been deported to the east. She is here in Lodz, Poland, with 140,000 other Jews. All those who escaped
the first pogroms are now locked up in ghettos. This is the case, in Kaunas,
for Dita Katz. With her mother,
her little brother Zvi, and her fiancé Yéhuda, Dita no longer harbors
any illusions about her fate. “I know since my father disappeared” “that the Nazis are
exterminating us.” “What is happening
is unimaginable” “and no one is helping us.” At the end of 1941, the Nazis, who occupied 
almost the entire Europe, launch the final solution. It is the second phase
of the Holocaust. From everywhere, in France
with the help of the Vichy regime. In Romania, in Yugoslavia, in Poland, Jews are grouped together then directed in panic to unknown destinations. It's from Holland, at the Westerbork
 transit camp, that we have the most precise testimony
of the deportation of the Jews. These images were taken
by German soldiers. They are unique documents. Every morning, a train takes several 
thousand people to the East. A Jewish nurse, Etty Hillesum,
attends the departure. “The cattle trucks are filling up
little by little.” “I see an elderly person going to
the last stage of the disease” “saying the prayer of the dead.” "The babies with squealing
little cries, ripped from their cribs." “Young women are already
sitting in the wagon.” “Are these doors really
going to close?” "Unfortunately, yes." "Thin openings still let
glimpses of faces." "Will we ever be able to
describe to the outside world" "what happened here?" For the world to realize the tragedy
that has affected the Jewish people, it will take another two years. Spring 1945, the end of the Second World War. After five years of nightmares, Europe celebrates victory
over the Nazi regime. One of the worst
the world has ever seen. During the winter, Allied and Soviet soldiers liberated dozens of extermination
and labor camps. Majdanek, Auschwitz, Bergen-Belsen. And the world has learned how
the majority of the victims perished. In gas chambers and crematories which sometimes still burn even
after the camps are liberated. The toll is 5 million Jewish victims, 6 million, as we learn a little later. How did the world let
this genocide happen? At a meeting of the
World Jewish Congress, one of the leaders
of the Zionist movement, Nahum Goldmann, let his anger out. The port of Haifa, in Palestine, a few months after
the end of the war. On makeshift boats sometimes
on the verge of sinking, the first survivors of the camps
reach the Holy Land. On one of these boats
is a Polish Jew, Garcher Rabinovich. “From where I am, Palestine
seems like a paradise to me.” “It's the first light
I've seen in 17 years.” “I am crying with joy.” “Do you know what it's like
to be welcomed somewhere” “after being hated” “and driven from
country to country?” Relief for some, but concern for others. Faced with the arrival of Jewish
survivors from Europe, once again, the Arabs of Palestine are protesting. In Jaffa, a teenager, Youssef Chaker,
asks the question. “Jews suffered horribly
during the Second World War.” “But we Arabs have
nothing to do with it.” “Why should we suffer
the consequences” “Nazi genocide
against the Jews?” "Why don't they create
their state in Europe," "where they were massacred," "instead of coming to us?" To deter any new Arab revolt, Great Britain continues to
apply its pre-war policy. It forbids Jews to
go to Palestine, but this time it gets all the undocumented
 immigrants arrested and groups them together
in camps. After the Nazi death camps, holocaust survivors experience British prison camps. They will react soon. In Europe, 150,000 Jewish survivors
 wait near former Nazi camps, like here, in Austria. They are reluctant to return
to Poland or Russia where they fear returning to the
antisemitism they have always known. Among them is Dita Katz, who miraculously survived
the death camps. Despite the death of her father in 1941 
and that of her husband in 1944, Dita chooses to return
to her hometown. In Lithuania, where she hopes to reunite
with her pre-war friends and rebuild her life. Her younger brother Zvi, the boy filmed in 1929, is now 18 years old. He too survived the Holocaust,
but he makes a different choice. With his mother, they decide to go to Palestine. To circumvent the British ban, he made contact with
an underground network and it's Zionist agents who are
going to take him all over Europe without identity documents and without a visa. In 1947, one of these trips was filmed by the
 American journalist Meyer Levin. By train, then by truck, Zvi and her mother
cross Poland, Czechoslovakia, Germany, Austria. After several weeks of travel, they are dropped off at the foot of
the Alps with a group of refugees and it is on foot that they will
cross the Italian border illegally. “There are women and children with us.” “But nothing can stop us
from reaching Palestine.” “We are 2,700 meters
above sea level,” “mom is not weakening.” “We feel sure of ourselves” “because we know that we will finally
have a country, like everyone else.” On the other side of the border, they embarked
on the Rome region at night, on a clandestine ship. It is from here that dozens of ships
take Jews to Palestine to land them
on a deserted beach. High-risk trips. One of these ships, the Exodus, was recently boarded
by the British fleet. The collision caused
several deaths and injuries and the Exodus was
sent back to Germany. This time, the Zionists want to
take every precaution. As soon as a ship is in sight, the 950 illegal passengers are
ordered to evacuate the deck and they take refuge
in the holds. Journalist Meyer Levin
continues filming while his partner, Tereska Torrès,
keeps a logbook. “This boat is a modern jellyfish raft.” “There is almost no air, no light,
only an unbreathable smell.” “Women, often hysterical, faint.” “Around 1 a.m. a little boy was born.” “The mother screamed
at the top of her lungs for two hours.” After 12 days of navigation, as the ship is nearing
its destination, a plane flies over
the illegal immigrants. It is followed by a British warship
who approaches and orders the machines
to be stopped. Unmasked, the passengers go out
into the open. For them, as Tereska Torrès
notes in her journal, The dream ends when the English soldiers
take control of the ship. “We are living the last hours
of the boat.” “As we get closer to Haifa,” “the city is rising before us,” “so beautiful" "and forbidden
to these poor people.” “A company of armed and helmeted
soldiers is waiting for us on the quay.” The passengers are all directed
to prison camps the British established
on the island of Cyprus. It is there, locked behind new barbed wires, that Zvi Katz and her mother
will spend several months. For them and for the Zionist activists, the situation has
become unbearable. In Palestine, Jewish armed groups
decide to take action and to launch a campaign of terror. Extremely violent attacks which aim to subdue the English
and drive them out of Palestine. On clandestine radio, an 18-year-old terrorist, Gueoulah Cohen threats. “You, British people,” “are going to pay for every tear of
a Jew who stretches out his hands" “and to whom you refuse help.” "Hell will enter your lives," "and terror will flood
every part of your body." “For we have taken an oath
to liberate the land of Israel.” In Palestine, Arab attacks are now
responding to Jewish attacks. And the region is once again
on the verge of explosion. Then news arrives from New York
that changes everything. It is November 29, 1947, at the
headquarters of the United Nations. An extraordinary general meeting
must be held on that day. One of those that will make history. Commission of inquiry, public hearing, speech. For a year, the international community has been
studying a solution for the Middle East and is preparing to vote on the
territorial division of Palestine. In green, the territories offered to the Arabs, in blue, those that are
offered to Jews. In the middle, the Jerusalem area, which would be administered
by the international community. The Zionists accepted the division, but the Arab countries all announced
that they would vote against it. To be adopted, the draft must receive
two-thirds of the votes. Undermined by guilt
over the Jewish people, The United States announced
that it would vote in favor and Great Britain that
it would abstain. The suspense concerns two countries. Tempted to the end by abstention, France has just given the Zionists
a helping hand. It is followed by the Soviet Union. It's unexpected, but the major powers
are swinging the vote. In a few minutes,
the cause of the Zionists has just progressed
like never before. In the crowd in Tel Aviv who explodes
with joy at the announcement of the news, there is the young Berliner
Bärbel Weiler. “Our dream is
becoming reality.” “The Jewish state is
getting closer to us.” “It's fantastic.” “We dance, we laugh, we sing.” “Everyone embraces each other
without knowing each other.” “What a joy!” They crossed the borders
clandestinely, reached their promised land
on makeshift ships, they now have the support
of the international community. At the end of 1947, the Zionists
seemed close to their goal. Will the two parties now succeed
in coming to an agreement? According to the UN, sharing must be followed
by two separate states, one Jewish, the other Arab. We will explain to you why did this project collapse
in only six months and how the creation of Israel plunged
the Arabs of Palestine into misery, and exile for decades. November 30, 1947,
the day after the UN vote. A young Arab from Jaffa,
Afif Elkouri, is revolted. “Why should we give away
half the country?” “For them to turn it
into a Jewish state?” “And what will happen
to non-Jews?” “Now there is only one solution,
to fight.” To defend their rights, thousands of peasants
are engaging in the guerrillas. One of their leaders
is Fawzi al-Qawuqji. One of the heroes of
the Great Arab Revolt of 1936. He has only a few weeks
to train his troops. “My soldiers have only basic weapons
that they bought themselves.” “We sent SOS to neighboring
Arab countries," "in vain" “Yet the hate is so intense that
we are ready to sacrifice ourselves.” In the opposite camp, The Haganah, the future army of Israel,
has been training for months. Supervised by veterans
of the Second World War, it is made up of highly motivated
young recruits. Among them is Zvi Katz, here,
on the right of the photo. He escaped from the Cyprus camp
thanks to a clandestine network. “All I think about is fighting.” “For us, it's a matter of dignity.” “We no longer want to be like animals
that are killed without saying anything.” “Never again will we allow ourselves
to be slaughtered like sheep.” The two young Berliners,
Ella and Bärbel Weiler, they too were involved
in the Haganah. They have just learned that their grandmother died
during the war in Poland. Assassinated by the Nazis. They are determined. “During the war," "no one acted to save the Jews.” “Today, we can only
count on ourselves.” “If we don't help ourselves," "who will help us?” In the spring of 1948, Fawzi al-Qawuqji and
the other Arab leaders launch their troops to attack
Jewish positions. One of the targets is the
kibbutz of Mishmar-Haémek, the crossing point
from Galilee to Tel Aviv. “We attack at 5 a.m.,
on the Sabbath day of the Jews.” “I give the order
to fire the cannon” “to destroy as many houses
as possible.” “They seem to have
a lot of losses.” Opposite, the kibbutz defenders
respond blow for blow. One of them, Joël Lotan,
films the fighting. “We're trying to repel the enemy.” “And we hope to hold out
until reinforcements arrive.” “Fortunately, after a few days,” “Haganah soldiers end up
joining us over the hills” “ from Haifa.” In a few days,
Palestine is on fire. Offensive, counteroffensive, the Haganah, better organized
than the Arab army, manages to gain the upper hand
within the first few weeks and to take thousands of prisoners. In the conquered cities,
the population is frightened, and is considering
fleeing the fighting. On April 9, 1948,
an event reinforced these fears. In Deir Yassin, Jewish extremists massacre
nearly 200 Arab villagers, including children. A carnage of which no image remains, but the news of which goes
around the world and triggers panic. In Jaffa, a few rare candid photos show residents abandoning
their homes and leaving the city. Among them is Youssef Chaker. “We heard about Deir Yassin
on the radio.” “We heard that the Arab countries
were coming to rescue us.” “In the meantime,
we prefer to leave.” “I get in a truck, we pile up
and we head to Beirut.” This is the beginning
of the Palestinian exodus. A few streets away is Afif Elkouri. “The whole city is fleeing.” “On Arabic radio, we are told that
we will be back in two weeks," “but is it for sure? “ Those who have fled will never
be allowed to return home. From now on, the city of Jaffa,
 deserted of its inhabitants, will officially be considered
an Israeli city. May 14, 1948,
the day everything changed. It is 10 a.m. in the port of Haifa. The British governor Alan Cunningham
 sets sail for England. Britain ends three decades
of presence in Palestine and leaves the two sides
face to face. Six hours later, in Tel Aviv, the leader of the Zionists,
David Ben Gurion, decides to proclaim the Jewish State. After years of struggle, the Zionists are reconnecting
with Jewish history. Behind their flag will be a
minority of the Arabs of Palestine. 150,000 people who
choose to stay there and who will become
Israeli citizens. Today, 60 years later, they represent 20% of the population. But most of the Arabs in Palestine
are on the road. Almost an entire population, men, women and children,
are now fleeing abroad. It is called the Nakba,
catastrophe in the Arabic language. The exodus that began in April
after the Deir Yassin massacre, will affect more than 700,000 people. Two thirds of the Arab population. The entry into war against Israel
by seven Arab countries the day after Ben Gurion's speech, doesn't change their fate. After several weeks of battle and the
 capture of the Old City of Jerusalem, after several spectacular advances, the Arab armies are retreating
and losing new territories. A situation that further reinforces
the flow of Palestinian refugees. According to the latest historical
 research conducted in Israel, half would have been
forcibly evicted by Israeli soldiers. They found refuge in
neighboring Arab countries, in Jordan or Lebanon,
in refugee camps. Among them is Abu Hicham, who is19. “They gave us tents.” “The ground is wet.” “We don't have
a country anymore.” “One can't live normally anymore.” “They give us bread and cheese.” "I feel humiliated and
I only think of one thing," "to return to my village." “As long as it takes, we will fight.” Hate, humiliation, exile. In 1948, The history of the Arab-Israeli conflict is just getting started. Today, Abu Hicham, 78,
still has refugee status. He lives in a Palestinian camp
on the outskirts of Beirut, Lebanon, a few kilometers from Afif Elkouri. For 60 years, neither has been allowed to return
to live in their native land, Palestine. Some have emigrated to the West, like Edward Said, the little
Christian Arab from Jerusalem. A university professor in New York, Edward Said was one of the most famous
spokespersons for the Palestinian people until his death in 2003. On the other hand, in Israel,
everyone tried to rebuild their lives despite the trauma
of the Second World War. Mickaël Arens, the young Zionist from Riga,
dedicated himself to agriculture in Galilee. Very marked by her childhood memories, the little Berliner Ella Weiler married a Jew who
came from Germany like her. They had two children. Her sister, Bärbel, married an Auschwitz survivor
of Polish origin. She lives with him in Tel Aviv. Grateful to her father
who died in the 1960s, for making him leave Germany
when there was still time. It was only in 1972 that Dita Katz
left Lithuania for Israel. There she met with her brother Zvi,
who had become a reserve officer. They live in Tel Aviv in the
memory of their loved ones murdered by the Nazis. Perhaps the most surprising
is Joel Iglinskiy. At the age of 99,
he still lives in Nekbah, the kibbutz he created in 1939. More than ever, he remains faithful to
the socialist ideal of his youth.

Oct '23 Hamas-Israel War: youtube.com/watch?v=N1TXC9eQcJ4

The Land of Israel has been referred to by many different names throughout its history- Canaan, Judah, Judea, Israel and Palestine. Each of these names has deep historical significance based on the inhabitants or conquerors of the land. 
 
Though modern day Israel was established in a land known as Palestine, named by the Romans who took control in the Second Century CE, its inhabitants have been historically Jewish since biblical times. No matter where Jewish people live across the world, the land of Israel continues to be their homeland.

Farha is a new film on Netflix depicting Israeli forces murdering a Palestinian family during the 1948 war surrounding Israel’s creation has been condemned by Israeli officials as “creating a false narrative”.  We are zooming out to give you a wider perspective of the events.

“Inside Israel, we are Palestinians too.” 

When solidarity protests erupted across the country in May, a Palestinian resident in the city of Lydd (or Lod, as Israel renamed it) told AJ+ that local Jewish Israelis marked their homes with red paint so they could be targeted for attacks by armed settlers.

This is part of a much larger project happening in Lydd, where ultranationalist Jewish Israelis have been moving into the city for over a decade with resources and support from the state. In the aftermath of recent violence that left two people dead, one Jewish and the other Palestinian, new levels of mistrust and generational trauma are haunting these residents. 

AJ+ went to Lydd to find out how Palestinians with Israeli citizenship are challenging the country’s de facto policy of divide and rule while demanding freedom from colonial oppression.

video_title: Can the Israeli-Palestinian Conflict be Solved? | History of Israel Explained | Unpacked
description:
Oct '23 Hamas-Israel War: youtube.com/watch?v=N1TXC9eQcJ4

This week, we’re asking a simple question - without a simple answer - why not end decades of fighting by creating a Palestinian state right alongside Israel?

The two-state solution might seem like a modern proposal, but over the years there have been plenty of attempts to establish an Arab state alongside a Jewish one.

In fact, there have been six recognizable attempts to establish a Palestinian state, that date back to before the War of Independence in 1948. 

So, why isn’t there a State of Palestine?

Like so many things, it all depends who you ask, with both sides blaming each other for the current circumstances...

Join us as we get to grips with this complicated situation, which seems to have no solution in sight.

video_title: Israel's Apartheid Against Palestinians: Cruel System of Domination and Crime Against Humanity
description:
TAKE ACTION HERE http://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/campaigns/2022/02/israels-system-of-apartheid 

Millions of Palestinians live under Israel’s system of apartheid, and at the heart of this violently racist system, is the Palestinian experience of being denied a home.  

For over 73 years, Israel has forcibly displaced entire Palestinian communities and demolished hundreds of thousands of Palestinians’ homes causing terrible trauma & suffering. Over 6 million Palestinians remain as refugees and today at least another 150,000 are at real risk of losing their homes.  

Israel has created and maintains laws, policies, and practices that deliberately oppress Palestinians and work to ensure Jewish Israeli domination across Israel and the Occupied Palestinian Territories (OPT). This includes racist seizures of property and planning laws and policies that make it impossible for many Palestinians to build homes. It also allows for mass demolitions of homes built without a permit, something that is routinely denied for Palestinians.  

Apartheid is a crime against humanity and is committed with the specific intent of maintaining a cruel system of control by one racial group over another. Every week, the Israeli authorities displace Palestinians through demolitions or forced evictions, which shows how Israel deliberately disadvantages Palestinians, giving them inferior status to Israeli Jews. 

With more stories coming to light and more people around the world mobilising against these injustices, now is the time for us to work together. As a first step, we must speak out for Palestinians living under Israel’s apartheid. We have the power to demolish this system even if it means one pillar at a time.

video_title: Gaza: 60-Minute Warning | Al Jazeera World Documentary
description:
In May 2021, missiles from Israeli jets struck and completely demolished four towers in Gaza – that is a fact. What was not clear was the reason for the attacks. Why were these buildings selected for destruction?

Israel claimed the towers were used by Hamas, whose military wing was launching rocket attacks on Israeli towns and cities at the time. Local Palestinians in Gaza, as well as international media and political leaders, disputed this and maintained that the towers housed only businesses, residential apartments and media organisations, including Al Jazeera Media Network and American news agency The Associated Press.

This film charts the story of the attacks - from the 60-minute evacuation warning to the question of the cost of rebuilding - and seeks to establish why these towers were singled out, bombed and destroyed.

video_transcript: foreign [Music] the Israel Palestine conflict is a complex and long-standing dispute with deep historical religious and political roots it has led to numerous Wars countless casualties and an ongoing humanitarian crisis the roots of the israel-palestine conflict go back to the late 19th century when Jewish immigrants began arriving in Palestine then part of the Ottoman Empire Jewish immigration was motivated by the Zionist movement which aimed to establish a Homeland for the Jewish people in Palestine this immigration coincided with the rise of Arab nationalism in the region which sought to establish an independent Arab state in Palestine after World War One the Ottoman Empire was dissolved and Palestine came under British control the British promised to support the establishment of a Jewish National home in Palestine while also respecting the rights of the Arab population however these two objectives conflicted and tensions between Jews and Arabs began to escalate in 1947 the United States proposed a partition plan that would divide Palestine into a Jewish state in an Arab state the Jewish leadership accepted the plan but the Arab leadership rejected it arguing that it violated the rights of the Palestinian people when Israel declared its independence in 1948 Arab forces from neighboring countries invaded the new state leading to a war that resulted in hundreds of thousands of refugees in the division of Palestine into three parts Israel the West Bank and Gaza since then the conflict has been marked by a series of wars [Music] expansion of Israeli settlements in the West Bank in East Jerusalem the construction of a separation barrier an ongoing violence and hostility the Palestinian Liberation Organization PLO was formed in the 1960s as the primary representative of the Palestinian people and it engaged in guerrilla warfare and terrorism against Israel in response Israel carried out military operations against PLO strongholds and occupied the West Bank in Gaza Strip in the 1967 war in the 1990s negotiations between Israel and the PLO had led to the Oslo Accords which created the Palestinian Authority PA and established a framework for a two-state solution however the Oslo process was derailed by the assassination of Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin the election of a hard-line government in Israel and the outbreak of a Palestinian Uprising in 2000 in the years since peace talks have stalled and the conflict has continued to simmer the current status of the conflict is Bleak Israel continues to expand settlements in the West Bank in East Jerusalem which are widely viewed as illegal under international law the PA is weak and divided and it's been unable to achieve its goal of establishing a viable and independent Palestinian state Gaza ruled by the Hamas Islamic group is under a blockade by Israel in Egypt leading to a humanitarian crisis and periodic flare-ups of violence the United States which has traditionally played a key role in the peace process has taken a pro-israel stance under the Biden Administration making it more difficult to achieve a resolution thank you [Music]
